Articles.Content:
Hey guys,

don't get me wrong, this is maybe a very silly and basic question but even after 1,5 year ksp i don't quite get the sense of the science lab.

What i understand so far is that i can add all my experiments on my spacecraft to the science lab, which then converts the experiments to data points.
Then the science lab  takes energy and the knowledge of scientist to convert these data points into science points which i then can transmit back to earth.

But why should i do this instead of directly transmit the science from the experiment or better take it back to earth with my kerbal ? 
Has the science lab something like an science multiplier, which increases the amount of science i can get from one experiment ? 

Would be very appreciated if someone can bring light in my very dark knowledge of science labs

Regards
Moritz

http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Mobile_Processing_Lab_MPL-LG-2

Yes, the experiments turned into more science by the lab are independent from experiments transmitted/recovered directly (without processing in a lab), and the ones in the lab give several times more science.

The multiplier is pretty significant, too. If you insert the experiment into the lab while situated in the same SOI the experiment was conducted in, you get a 625% yield. Otherwise, it's still 500%. (There's also an additional x1.1 multiplier for being landed on any surface other than Kerbin, but it's rarely relevant.)

And as TheDestroyer said, you can use the lab in addition to transmitting/recovering an experiment, and get full credit for both. You just need to take two readings and process one of them while taking the other one back. Getting 72.5 science for an experiment worth 10 is a pretty sweet haul.

(Of course, even without the lab you can easily complete the tech tree before going interplanetary... but it does help a lot with modded tech trees.)
Note that even if you don't need the science points (since they tend to max out quite early) you can use strategies to convert 'excess' science to funds or rep.

Another thing is that, if you collect two copies of the same data (eg, do experiment, have kerbal grab it and store it in a pod, then redo the experiment), you can put one copy in the lab and transmit or send back the other copy.  So you can get even more than the lab-multiplied amount.

Try a craft that can land on Minmus, consisting of a crewed lab, all the experiments, antenna (don't forget it!) and some two gigantors or so.

Perform the experiments. Add to lab as many as will fit (for 750 data points). Don't forget surface sample, crew report and eva report normal, and "in space low" (just jump up and perform report mid-jump),

Wait till data is processed into science. Transmit, add more experiments. Once you run out of experiments, hop to another biome Perform gravity scan mid-flight too. Rinse, repeat.

An experiment that can yield 120 science returned to Kerbin, will yield 750 science or more from the lab. Processing one location can take a couple years, true, but the amount of science you collect is staggering.

You can also have multiple science labs processing the same experiment at the same time for unique science points, as long as they are each part of a different craft. So that means you can put 10 or 20 scientists into HKO with 10 science labs, and have your tech tree done without even heading to the moons.

Note however that there is a pretty significant speed bonus for higher-ranking scientists, though, so it is definitely to your benefit to bring a schoolbus load of scientists to Minmus, land and collect the science there, bring them all back for two stars, and then do the orbital battle school research complex.

Edited August 25, 2016 by dire

The lab is a game mechanic which encourages players to send long-term, manned missions away from Kerbin.  It gives you greater value from manned missions than from tiny probes which do one thing then leave.  Without the lab (and related mechanics like materials lab reset), it'd be difficult to justify manned missions in terms of game money for science gained.

 

Edited August 25, 2016 by Corona688
For missions to more distant planets, the lab may actually be quicker than a return flight and lighter than the fuel that would be needed to return multiple science samples.
